title: Unstable Pelvic Fracture
diagnosis_topic: High-energy pelvic fracture with massive hemorrhage
setup_script: “A 35-year-old motorcyclist is brought in after a high-speed collision. He was intubated in the field. On arrival, he is pale and diaphoretic with gross deformity of the pelvis. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 70/40 mmHg, HR 140 bpm, RR 24/min on ventilator, Temp 36 °C.
Airway secured, breath sounds equal, pelvis unstable with crepitus; long bone deformity of left leg noted.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident applies pelvic binder at the greater trochanters

dynamic_flow.reply: Negative for intraperitoneal fluid but poor window due to bowel gas.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates massive transfusion protocol with balanced blood products
dynamic_flow.reply: BP rises to 90/60 mmHg after four units transfused.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders AP pelvis X-ray
dynamic_flow.reply: Open-book fracture with pubic symphysis diastasis and sacroiliac joint disruption.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults interventional radiology for pelvic angioembolization
dynamic_flow.reply: IR arranges emergent pelvic embolization to control venous bleeding.
Orthopedics applies temporary external fixator after embolization to stabilize pelvis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays binder placement and resuscitation
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops profound shock and cardiac arrest.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses for associated injuries
dynamic_flow.reply: Once stable, CT head and chest reveal left femur shaft fracture requiring later repair.
Begin once bleeding controlled and patient stabilized.
Pelvic reconstruction once resuscitated; address associated orthopedic injuries.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of pelvic fracture as source of life-threatening hemorrhage
Application of pelvic binder and initiation of massive transfusion protocol
Appropriate sequencing of imaging and intervention (angioembolization vs. external fixation)
Assessment for associated injuries and secondary survey
Timing of definitive fixation and postoperative care

anchors.1: Does not recognize pelvic fracture as a potential source of shock
anchors.2: Delayed recognition; incomplete consideration of pelvic hemorrhage
anchors.3: Identifies pelvic fracture as possible cause but omits key alternatives
anchors.4: Recognizes unstable pelvic fracture as likely cause; considers differential appropriately
anchors.5: Excellent diagnostic reasoning with prompt identification and systematic exclusion of other causes

anchors.1: Fails to initiate resuscitation or binder placement; dangerously delayed actions
anchors.2: Recognizes urgency but delays critical steps or orders inappropriate tests
anchors.3: Initiates resuscitation and workup but with errors in timing or prioritization
anchors.4: Appropriately prioritizes binder placement, transfusion, imaging, and interventions
anchors.5: Excellent judgment anticipating complications, coordinating care, and ensuring timely sequencing

anchors.2: Provides information but lacks structure or clarity
anchors.3: Communicates findings and plan clearly but incompletely
anchors.4: Clear, structured, empathetic communication with team
anchors.5: Exemplary, succinct, and anticipates team/patient needs

anchors.1: Lacks understanding of operative or procedural management of pelvic fractures
anchors.2: Identifies operative options but with significant knowledge gaps
anchors.3: Describes key steps of management with some omissions
anchors.4: Comprehensive description of management, complications, and alternatives
anchors.5: Mastery of current evidence, operative nuances, and perioperative care of pelvic fractures

anchors.3: Respectful but requires prompting for reflection
anchors.4: Consistently respectful, accountable, receptive to feedback
anchors.5: Role model professionalism; demonstrates humility, cultural sensitivity, and ethical conduct

resident_feedback_template:
Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the pelvic fracture as a source of life-threatening hemorrhage. You appropriately applied a binder and activated the massive transfusion protocol. Your sequencing of interventions showed sound prioritization.
Areas for Improvement:At times, decisions regarding when to escalate to angiography or external fixation could have been more clearly articulated. Continue working on integrating multidisciplinary coordination with trauma, orthopedic, and interventional teams in real time.
Suggested Reading Topics:- Management of Unstable Pelvic Fractures (EAST Guidelines)- Massive Transfusion Protocols in Trauma (ACS Resources for Optimal Care of the Injured Patient)- Operative and Non-Operative Management of Pelvic Ring Injuries (SCORE Curriculum)
